p.seg: As for Han Fei
he was one of the princes of Han.
He took pleasure in the study of 'titles and performance' and 'the arts of the rule of law',
but his ultimate basic concern was with the the Huang-Lao (Daoism).
As a matter of personal detail, Fei had a stutter
and was incapable of speaking in public.
but he excelled at the composition of texts.
Together with Li Si he studied under Xun Qing,
and there Si had an inferiority complex vis-a-vis Fei.
When Fei realised that (his state of) Han was being decimated and weakened
he repeatedly remonstrated with the King of Han through letters.
The King of Han (however) was incapable of using his advice.
At this point Han Fei took strong exception to the failure - in government - to make it one's main business to cultivate to transparency the system of the rule of law.
(the failure to) maintain a firm grip on one's position of power in controlling ministers and subjects
to enrich the state and strengthen its armies and on that basis to seek a staff, and to employ men of talent,
and instead the practice of appointing to high office frivolous vermin and of placing them in charge of men of concrete achievement and substance.
He was of opinion that that Confucians confused the rule of law through there literary works,
and that the roving knights used their arms to offend against prohibitions.
that in stressless times one should show fondness for men of a high reputation
and in stressed conditions one should employ armoured officers.
In his own time those who were fostered were not employed,
and what was applied was not cherished and cultivated.
